thread.title: Booting Up: Iris scans better than chips for card security
thread.title_full: Booting Up: Iris scans better than chips for card security | Boston Herald

author: Jessica Van Sack
title: Booting Up: Iris scans better than chips for card security
text:
Booting Up: Iris scans better than chips for card security An eye to future of payment Jessica Van Sack Monday, October 12, 2015 comments Tweet If you want to know how to prevent credit card fraud, look no further than the new Windows Hello login feature, which recognizes a user’s face and iris, logging them instantly into their new device.
Consumers and merchants alike should demand that the long-term plan for credit card security involves licensing that technology from Microsoft — or a competitor.
Unfortunately, the motivation to change is limited for banks and credit card companies. Most of the costs related to fraud are passed on to merchants and consumers. That’s why the magnetic stripe has been in place for the last 40 years.
This month, the new federal standard for credit card payment terminals became the microchip. But let’s not kid ourselves about chip-embedded credit cards — fraud isn’t going to decline in any significant way. Chips are a half-step. Our credit card transactions will still be less secure than nearly every country in the G-20 because of a lack of willingness on the part of banks and credit card companies to institute a simple PIN number as a security check — the same PINs that are required for a bank’s ATM. The same PIN technology that in the United Kingdom has caused merchant fraud losses to fall by 67 percent.
But with the advent of Windows Hello, we now have a way to bring the numbers of lost and stolen card fraud to zero.
Biometric technology is at the point where it’s basically 100 percent reliable. Consumers wouldn’t even have to carry a credit card. They would just look into a point-of-sale camera and the device would ask which method of payment they’d want to use. There would be no credit card number to steal.
While new Windows phones contain iris scanners that recognize the patterns on the colored part of the eye, desktop devices go farther. New laptops that contain the Intel RealSense 3D Camera use infrared light to look for thermal signatures on your face. The camera senses depth, and therefore cannot be tricked by a photo.
Payment terminals that featured a RealSense camera would basically be foolproof. To give you an idea of cost and feasibility, the Intel RealSense developer kit is priced at $99 and works like a normal Web cam.
Obviously there’s a downside here, and that’s privacy. But, consumers still have the option of carrying cash. And I’d argue you can’t expect the way your face looks to be considered private, especially in our YouTube-ubiquitous world.
We’re about to enter an era where our apps and email are more secure than a good chunk of our finances. And that’s something every American should be concerned about.
